description: From Middle English spous, spouse, from Anglo-Norman espus m, espuse f and Old French espos m, espose f and by aphesis from Latin spōnsus m (“bridegroom”), spōnsa f (“bride”), from spondeō (“I vow, pledge”), from Proto-Indo-European *spend-. Displaced native Old English ġemaca.

entries.meaning: A person in a marriage or marital relationship.
examples: People should treat their spouses with respect.

verbs.description: spouse (third-person singular simple present spouses, present participle spousing, simple past and past participle spoused)

examples: Of any proof against the honourableness
Of Lady Auranthe, our new-spoused daughter?
